Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Genetic Networks of Bract Suppression in Maize
Award.AbstractNarration:
Since maize (corn) is one of the most important and productive agricultural crops both in the United States and world wide, a clear understanding of maize leaf development could inform attempts to improve productivity. Critical gaps, however, remain towards understanding how leaves initiate during the earliest stages of growth. In this project, genes that control leaf initiation will be identified by investigating maize mutants that fail to suppress leaves after the reproductive transition. Reproductive leaf (or bract) suppression presents a promising means to identify genes acting in the earliest stages of leaf initiation. The project will use genome-wide techniques identify the network of genes that are regulating maize bract outgrowth. Since bract suppression has evolved multiple times, these results should also shed light on the evolution of developmental mechanisms.

In order to increase public understanding of evolutionary mechanisms, the project will develop novel curriculum and assessment materials designed identify and address misconception related to evolutionary thinking. Specifically, an assessment that can reveal common misconceptions related to evolutionary trees will be developed, and future high school teachers will be trained to teach biological diversity from an evolutionary framework. The ability to interpret evolutionary trees is key to biological literacy, but the necessary skills are rarely taught and often poorly understood by high school teachers. Ten future teachers and one biology education graduate student involved in this project will be given state of the art training in the nature of science and be uniquely qualified to address this hole in the evolution curriculum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF CAREER grant enabled the completion of research and education aims concerning the origin and evolution of novel traits. The research aims focused on understanding the genetic regulation of leaf formation in maize (corn) flowering structures, while the education aims were centered on identifying and helping students overcome common misconceptions related to the interpretation of evolutionary trees.

 

Cereal grass flowering heads (including corn, rice, wheat, barley and sorghum) are the ultimate source for the overwhelming majority of calories consumed by humans. Modification of the inflorescence (flowering head) can influence overall yield, and crop domestication and improvement have both involved significant alteration of grass inflorescence architecture. Our research aims included investigating two kinds of maize (corn) genes that contribute to inflorescence architecture. The first genes, known collectively as tassel sheath genes play a unique role in inflorescence development by strongly inhibiting leaf development that would otherwise accompany inflorescence branching. Through a combination of genetic and molecular approaches we showed that tassel sheath genes not only inhibit leaf growth, but also promote growth of the branch they are associated with. These tassel sheath genes appear to cooperate with other genes important for establishing boundaries early in development. Together, these tassel sheath and boundary genes create a signaling center that promotes branching, and thus prolificacy, of the grass inflorescence.  Evolutionary analysis of these genes indicates that this signaling center is a novel feature that arose in the grass family.  The second class of genes is represented by a single locus known as Few branched. Unlike the tassel sheath genes, Few branched inhibits inflorescence branching, and appears to act from a distinct signaling center that influences the early growth decisions of inflorescence branching. Evolutionarily, Few branched also appears to constitute a novel developmental process that is specific to the grass family. Together, Few branched and tassel sheath regulate opposing mechanisms that control branching during the early stages of inflorescence development. These findings provide novel insights into the genetic regulation of cereal grass inflorescence architecture. Future work will further clarify the role of tassel sheath and Few branched genes in inflorescence branching including possible avenues to enhance grain yield. Funding for these research aims directly supported STEM training of two postdocs, 14 undergraduates and a career enhancement via a sabbatical for the principal investigator.

 

As the unifying theory of all biology, an accurate understanding of evolution is foundational to biological science education. Evolution was succinctly described by Darwin as Descent with Modification. Currently, most of the evolution curriculum focuses on improving student understanding of mechanisms of Modification (e.g. mutation, natural selection, drift, etc.), while significantly less time is given to improving the concept of Descent from common ancestors. Common ancestry is represented in biology by the phylogenetic tree and multiple studies have shown that students harbor deep seated misconceptions about evolutionary descent that makes reading and interpreting phylogenetic trees (i.e. tree-thinking) difficult. We embarked on a two-pronged approach to first assess and then address common student misconceptions around tree-thinking. Working with both biology major and non-major students we identified a core set of common misconceptions and developed a concept inventory to assess their prevalence and persistence. This assessment was paired with development of novel active learning approaches to improve student tree-thinking skills. We showed that sustained focus on tree-thinking skills over a semester-long course in plant diversity was affective in addressing even the most deep-seated tree-thinking misconceptions. Our assessment is now published and readily available. Over the course of this project we trained one Bioscience Education PhD., eight pre-service and seven in-service high school biology teachers.
